results.title: Image contagion
results.brief_description: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny.

constellations_primary.name: Confronting injustice on-screen
constellations_primary.description: The Black Lives Matter movement and the treatment of African Americans at the hands of authorities is explored in this Constellation that connects hip-hop, the Civil Rights Movement and representation in Hollywood.

results.description: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. Our relationship to the moving image has shifted from consumption to production. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny. Coupled with social media, the moving image can affect political, social and cultural change; smartphones are able to help topple governments, transmit ideas and defend civil rights. Yet the moving image is also easily manipulated, making it an important arena in the battle for reality.
description_for_label: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. Our relationship to the moving image has shifted from consumption to production. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny. Coupled with social media, the moving image can affect political, social and cultural change; smartphones are able to help topple governments, transmit ideas and defend civil rights. Yet the moving image is also easily manipulated, making it an important arena in the battle for reality.

results.title: Image and screen
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Lessons in visual language”.
Notes how advances in technology have created greater realism on the screen. Shows how the definition or clarity of detail of the photographed image can be altered by filters, vaseline and netting. Also explains depth of field and exposure. Narrated by Peter Thomson. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Image and Impact
results.creator_credit: Sandra Ostertag, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, CBS, KOCE-TV (Television station : Huntington Beach, Calif.) and Coast Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Photographic vision”.
Introduces the philosophy of this 20 part course which previews program guests and concepts to be taught over the series. Photographic vision is seen as a means of personal growth and individual expression.

results.title: Illustrations of radiation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Transference of Heat”.
Explains how heat sources emit radiations both as heat waves or infra-red waves and as light waves; how objects absorbing heat radiations rise in temperature; how heat is produced in glass-houses and how such glass-houses are cooled; explains the effects of clouds on radiation from the sun; shows how the shape of the earth results in different concentrations of the sun’s radiation at the poles and at the equator.

group_siblings.title: Illustrations of convection
group_siblings.creator_credit: Realist Films

results.title: Illustrations of convection
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Transference of Heat”.
The film is divided into three parts: the first part shows convection in water as illustrated by the working of a central heating system and a motor coar cooling system. The second part shows convection in air with ventilation in a room with windows first open and then closed, as examples. The third part of the film illustrates the difference between a sea breeze and a land breeze.

results.title: Illustrations of conduction
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Transference of Heat”.
The film is divided into three parts: the first illustrates conduction in different substances, good and bad conductors and the insulation of a refrigerator; the second shows the method of lagging boilers and hot and cold pipes; the third shows various examples of poor heat conductors - wool, fur, feathers and snow.

results.title: Illustrating absence
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Carland, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a researcher it was natural for Rebecca Carland to be curious and begin the unravelling. She tells of her obsession with illustrator Arthur Bartholomew, a relationship that has continued in his absence and long after the project concluded.

results.title: Illusions of reality
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Developing image”.
Portrays the public’s belief in the photograph and the ways that this trust has been manipulated over the years. Viewers explore photographs taken at the Battle of Gettysburg with a Civil War historian, while contemporary photographer Duane Michals, discusses illusion in his personal and commercial work.

results.title: Illuminations
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Tibor Markus and Australia Council
results.brief_description: A young couple live in an almost hallucinatory world. Through the death of the girl’s father a sense of the infinite develops between them. Their love gives both of them enough self knowledge to become highly alert and sensitive. They become free and detached from the normal anxieties, pressures fears and hopes of society. “Illuminations” makes an attempt at extending consciousness beyond the limits imposed by our ego. Man always underestimates the power of the mind and confuses it with his own man-made illusions. Cast: Gabriella Trsek, Anthony Llewellyn Jones Norman Kaye, Sheila Florence, Athol Smith, Tibor Markus.
